qas.question: What restrictions do Windows upgrade licenses have?

answers.text: require an existing version of Windows to install

qas.question: What did Windows offer in place of a full version of the software?
What did the System Builder SKU take the place of?
What did the Personal Use License allow?

answers.text: purchase and personal use by users on homebuilt computers

plausible_answers.text: require an existing version of Windows to install

qas.question: What restrictions don't Windows upgrade licenses have?
What did Windows offer in place of a preview version of the software?
What did the System Builder SUK take the place of?

plausible_answers.text: purchase and personal use by users on homebuilt computers

qas.question: What did the Personal Use License disallow?

context: Unlike previous versions of Windows, Windows 8 was distributed at retail in "Upgrade" licenses only, which <a0_0><b5_0>require an existing version of Windows to install<b5_0/><a0_0/>. The "full version software" SKU, which was more expensive but could be installed on computers without an eligible OS or none at all, was discontinued. In lieu of full version, a <a1_0><b6_0>specialized "System Builder" SKU<b6_0/><a1_0/> was introduced. The "System Builder" SKU replaced the <a3_0><b8_0>original equipment manufacturer<b8_0/><a3_0/> <a2_0><b7_0>(OEM) SKU<b7_0/><a2_0/>, which was only allowed to be used on PCs meant for resale, but added a "Personal Use License" exemption that officially allowed its <a4_0><b9_0>purchase and personal use by users on homebuilt computers<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
